'Poles' ( ; singular masculine: Polak, feminine: Polka) â a nation of
predominantly West Slavic origin and native to Central Europe, inhabiting mainly
Poland and some other European and American countries. The present population of
Poles living in Poland is estimated to 35 538 000.

The preamble to the Constitution of the Republic of Poland defines the Polish
nation as comprising all the citizens of Poland. Poland's inhabitants live in
the following historic regions of the country: Wielkopolska, MaÅopolska, Mazovia
(), Silesia (), Pomerania (), Kujawy, Warmia, Mazury, and Podlasie. A wide-
ranging Polish diaspora exists throughout Europe (Germany, France, the United
Kingdom, Russia, Belarus, Lithuania and Ukraine), the Americas (the United
States, Brazil and Argentina) and Australia. In 1960, Chicago in the United
States, had the world's largest urban Polish population after
Warsaw. "Sections of North Milwaukee Avenue are Main Street for Chicago's
huge Polish population (the second-largest urban concentration after Warsaw's)"
[in:] Chicago for Dummies by Laura Tibert 2007. p. 125; "DID YOU KNOW? Chicago,
with nearly a million residents of Polish extraction, is often cited as the
world's second-largest Polish city after Warsaw." [in:] Poland by Neil Wilson,
Tom Parkinson, Richard Watkins, 2005, p. 33; "In 1960, Chicago claimed 700 000
residents of Polish descent, making it the American city with the largest Polish
community and, after Warsaw, the second largest aggregation of urban Poles in
the world." [in:] Human development by James O. Lugo, Gerald L. Hershey,
1979 Today, the largest urban concentration of Poles is the Katowice urban
agglomeration known as the Silesian Metropolis of 2.7 million inhabitants.

Over a thousand years ago, the Polans of Giecz, Gniezno and PoznaÅ â an
influential tribe in Wielkopolska â succeeded in uniting Lechitic tribes
under what became the Piast dynasty, Gerard Labuda. Fragmenty dziejÃ³w
SÅowiaÅszczyzny zachodniej, t.1-2 p.72 2002; Henryk ÅowmiaÅski. PoczÄtki Polski:
z dziejÃ³w SÅowian w I tysiÄcleciu n.e, t. 5 p.472; StanisÅaw Henryk Badeni,
1923. p. 270 thus giving rise to the Polish state.
